name: Red River Hog
description: It has cinnamon-brown coloration, a white belly, and a black-and-white mask on its head and face. A strip of longer white hairs runs along its back, and long hairs also grow on its ears. Males have hard facial protuberances that act as buffers during skirmishes.
proportions: Body length 1–1.5 m, tail length 30–45 cm, shoulder height 55–100 cm, weight 50–130 kg
attractions: In their homeland, they inhabit wetlands along riverbanks, especially in forested and bushy areas. In the evening and during the day, groups of red river hogs set out to forage. They tirelessly dig through the soil, searching for tubers, roots, and small animals. They form permanent pairs, and both parents jointly protect their striped young.
breeding: We’ve kept them since 2001. Since the African House exhibit isn’t designed for breeding, we only display males.
